subject: Cooking
title: Yogurt: Milk's Controlled Transformation
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Yogurt: Milk's Controlled Transformation.

hook.text: Heat milk to 110Â°F, add a spoon of yogurt, wait 8 hours. Bacteria do all the work.

buildup.text: Lactobacillus and Streptococcus thermophilus convert lactose into lactic acid, thickening and souring the milk.

discovery.text: The acid denatures milk proteins (casein), causing them to coagulate into yogurt's characteristic thick texture.

twist.text: Greek yogurt is just regular yogurt with the whey strained out â€” doubling protein and halving volume.

climax.text: Turkish people have been making yogurt for over 4,000 years â€” the word 'yogurt' itself is Turkish.

punchline.text: Yogurt is just milk that bacteria decided to thicken.

quiz.question: What does lactic acid do to milk proteins during yogurt making?
options: Causes them to coagulate and thicken
